name: Dal-Motki Chaat
instructions: Wash the Motki Dal well in water and soak it for at least 3-4 hours.
After soaking, take it out of the water and tie it in a cloth to allow it to sprout. Wet the cloth and tie it securely.
Hang the cloth near a water source (e.g., tap) and keep it wet continuously for at least 2 nights. This will help the seeds sprout.
Once the Dal has sprouted, put it in a pan. Add water, a little salt, and a little turmeric. Boil it until it remains crunchy but is slightly cooked.
While the Dal is boiling, prepare the chutney. In a bowl, mix dry mango powder, black salt, sugar, a little salt, chili powder, and roasted cumin seeds. Add water and mix to avoid lumps.
Once the Dal has come to a boil and has a nice color, turn off the gas and strain the Dal. Set it aside to cool.
In a fresh pan, add the dry mango powder mixture and cook it. The dry mango powder will thicken the chutney as it boils. Add enough water to achieve a flowy consistency.
Cook the chutney for 3-4 minutes until it is thin and runny. Turn off the gas and let it cool. As it cools, it will thicken further.
Pour the cooled chutney into a separate container. Save as much chutney as possible, even if it spills slightly during pouring.
For assembling the chaat, take the Dal Mod and put it in a big bowl or platter.

Add boiled and peeled potato (chopped), cucumber (chopped), chopped tomatoes, green chili, chopped coriander, pomegranate seeds, chopped onion, a little salt, black salt, generous amounts of chaat masala, and the Amchur chutney. Squeeze a little lemon on top.
Mix everything thoroughly until the chaat is well combined and aromatic.
For an alternative plating, take a cucumber and make a 'cucumber boat.' Cut the cucumber in half lengthwise. Use a spoon to scrape out the seeds and hollow out a space in the middle.
Fill the cucumber boat with the prepared Dal Mod Chaat and serve. Enjoy!
